623262404.name: Superb - Really a must see attraction!
623262404.author: a TripAdvisor user
623262404.reviewBody:
A relaxing Sunday in Agua's ... Cool so a good time to visit Parque Tres Centurias... Which has the Train Museum Inside too!
So parked up - There is a free car park here.
Walked in and paid the $10 peso for 2 entrance fee.
Walked into the museo - Big and well laid out... All the descriptions are in Spanish so be prepared to translate.
Very good exhibition - shows the history and some tragedies for the N de M lines.
Had a good walk around and at the end an assistant offered to take some photo;s of us.. Very helpful guy - And so polite too... Nice!
Took a walk around and watched to model train exhibition - kidz will love this.!
The wakled into the old Agua's station building - loved that!
Went outside and in front of us are stores to buy drinks snacks etc. 
We then walked around the static display of old caches and was amazing to see the president of Mexico's Pullman from early 1900's.
After this we went into Cafe Tranvia - Highly recommend this! For a coffee y waffle :-)
Finally a walk around the park.. You must see the hero's corner.. great tribute to some incredible men... Slow walk around the park and then off..
I would highly recommend this - Really I loved it :-)

542108017.author: a TripAdvisor user
542108017.reviewBody: it is a small nice park with a couple of attractions: "dancing" musical fountain and small rail road museum with a few pieces of equipment stationed outside. The fountain was pretty, took our attention for 15 minutes, rather enjoyable. The museum is not great, not many interesting exhibits. They tried to center the presentation around a major rail disaster that took place many years ago, but it was not really worth the visit. On the the other hand, the entrance fee was really small, so get in, you have nothing to lose. Some of the rail cars outside were more interesting, but you cannot get inside. So all in all, it was not spectacular, but if you have a few free hours during the weekend, it is worth the visit.

539266522.name: Interesting Place
539266522.author: a TripAdvisor user
539266522.reviewBody:
This is an interesting place in the sense that it is part railroad museum and part park. They have a "dancing waters" kind of attraction going on, where fountains of water "dance" to music. I saw it during the day and it was OK, but I can imagine that in the evening, with colored lights, it must look pretty cool.

There are several train cars scattered throughout the park, from different eras of the railroad industry. There is also a railroad museum as well, that only charges 5 pesos, which is like getting charged a few cents. Interestingly enough, the museum's space is mainly devoted to all of the train wrecks that have been recorded in Aguascalientes and the local areas, over the last 100 years or so. It's actually kind of sad and tragic. There were some horrific train wrecks back in the day.

I unfortunately arrived after the Day of the Dead festivities, so there were a lot of cleaning crews in full force getting everything cleaned up. As a result, I don't think I got to experience the grounds as they usually are. Even so, there are a lot of places to walk around, and many benches as well, when it's time for a breather.

There is a neat little railroad car that doubles as a restaurant. The owner and her daughter were very nice. At the time I went, I was the only one there. I ordered a ham and cheese sandwich that was served on a roll and a diet Pepsi. With tip about 100 pesos ($5.00) It was quite good. They played some great music that went perfect with the railroad car and the overall ambiance. Definitely a place to check out when getting the Hungry's 

A group or person visiting could spend a good half day here, if they took the time to experience all the park had to offer.

332363914.name: Great if you\'re into trains
332363914.author: a TripAdvisor user
332363914.reviewBody:
Located about a 20 minute walk from Centro Aguascalientes, the Plaza de las Tres Centurias is a tourist complex built around remnants of the railroad industry. While it has park-like elements, it is more like a large outdoor historic site, rather than a park. Many of the attractions posted in traveler pictures were not open or available when I went in July. I'm not sure if this was temporary, but if not, I don't think kids would be very interested in this site. I did not see a park train ride, nor could I enter the train model, or the cargo exhibit hall. Nevertheless, if you like trains and history, there is much to see here if you have the time. The park highlights three centuries of railroad development: the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries. 

The modern focus of this park features a large park area with a sports complex, grass and sports fields, concrete paths that line the park, and park benches. Although there are trees, shade is not plentiful here. The weather in Aguascalientes is mild year-round, so it isn't much of an issue, but in July, I definitely felt the power of the sun's rays as I walked around. (*A more lush and garden-like park to visit would be the Jardin de San Marcos)
To the left of the sports complex, lies a huge concrete building which appeared to be some kind of cargo exhibit center. The day I went, they were setting up for a concert inside the building, so it was closed to visitors. Peering through the windows, it seemed to contain large, heavy machinery on display, most likely steam engine pipes and parts.   A few railroad wagons are placed in front of this building, and an old train engine sits on a bridge near a black stone wall which rises dramatically from the large concrete patio. Writing and a picture of a train is etched on the wall, but time and neglect has faded and chipped its surface, and the writing is no longer legible. The train image was so poor, I didn't even take a picture of it. The old train depot (the second one) has been renovated into a library and dance center, and in a building nearby, a group was practicing folklorico dancing. 

The section across the street is more dedicated to the history of the early locomotive and the railway's influence on the culture of Aguascalientes. Here there are more sights for families and kids. The entrance is free, and there is an information booth (spanish-speaking). This outdoor complex is well marked with signposts, directing you to the various sights and activities. A well-maintained locomotive, The Hidrocálida, is on display amid a long shallow pool with fountains. There are a few bronze statues nearby depicting railroad workers and their families. 
The original train depot has been renovated into tourist traps, and below it is a shaded food court area and small cafe serving coffee and a few menu items out of a renovated train car. On the station platform, an old passenger car displays its original furniture and red velvet seats. Some travelers have posted pictures inside this car, but it was not open when I went. I could only peer through the dirty windows of the car.
A small park within the historical section (within the Tres Centurias park) features large, green trees which shade a few paths that wind among bushes and statues of prominent historical figures of the railroad. In the center, is a rectangular fountain with a Dancing Water show every few hours. Be sure to ask for the times at the information booth. The  water was murky, and I was dubious that the show would be worth seeing, but the man at the visitor's booth kept reminding me what time the show would start - 2:00! - (though it didn't actually start until 2:15), so it was important to HIM that I see it. It's no Vegas fountain show, but I did enjoy it. The water is choreographed to warbly, distorted music, and there isn't any colored lighting, but it is programmed well, has several different spurts of varying heights and patterns, and often shoots up to an impressive 12 meters. Worth seeing if you are there. It's free.

In the back of this park, you can see The Monumental Clock, built in honor of workers in the Roundhouse. A giant flagpole displays a 17-meter flag 30 meters high. A small museum features a photo gallery and displays of the development of the railroad. Entry is 5 pesos, or 30 cents. 

In sum, this is a good place to visit if you have a few hours to look around and a keen interest in history. If all of the exhibits are open, and the train is running, kids would enjoy it. If not, you're probably better off visiting the interactive museum of science, or the indoor mall with an arcade / play area near the Plaza de Toros. Otherwise, the nearby mountain ranges offer a variety of outdoor activities, such as hiking, camping, ziplining, or swimming in the hot springs. 

Hope that helps!  Enjoy Aguascalientes!

A recreational, cultural and historic space, built on the grounds of the Old National Mexican Railroad Station. In this park we find the “Dancing Water Fountain”, the Rail Road Museum and the Mural “La Maestranza”, and the “Antigua Nave de Locomotoras” Exposition Center.

-free to wander, large, historical
-train depot and old models on one side, bldg with train equip was closed, setting up for a concert
-Old station renovated to dance school     
-across the street is oldest century with stream locomotive model
-info desk
-clean, free bathrooms w/ tp and soap
-restaurant
-fountain show at 2:15
-small museum 5 pesos

248560140.name: The dancing water fountains are amazing!
248560140.author: a TripAdvisor user
248560140.reviewBody:
We visited this park before and we enjoyed it so much, that we wanted our curious four years old daughter to enjoy it this time!
First, we enjoyed the little ride train around the park with a wonderful tour guide who explained the history behind the name of the park and the old train carts at the museum as well as the old and new buildings.
Then, we were ready to enjoy the show of the dancing water fountains; our daughter had a blast dancing to the different songs playing while the colors illuminating the fountain were changing as the water were dancing as well to the rhythm!
We got some hot drinks and walked around the exhibits!
The only side down was that the "clock" was under maintenance this time, and it is one of the main attractions besides the water fountains. I am sure as soon as they go back to the whole park in action it will be amazing as it was before or even much better.

367665934.author: a TripAdvisor user
367665934.reviewBody: This Cathedral was built in 1704, 311 years ago. Started by Spanish Missionaries, Aguascalientes was founded as a small mining settlement during Spanish Conquest. These kind of Cathedrals were the symbol of the Spanish Crown Power of those days. Beautifully decorated with New-Hispanic baroque imagery, is the religious center of Aguascalientes City. Recommended to first-time visitor by locals.

586554313.name: Really exciting and challenging experience, need to be reasonably fit!
586554313.author: a TripAdvisor user
586554313.reviewBody: This is an aerial adventure course that consists of several obstacle trails, two zip lines, and some moderate rock climbing. It gives you a shot of adrenaline, but it is very secure. The courses are suspended on steel ropes over a small gorge with a small lake at the bottom, the vertical distance to the lake is only about 20 m, but it feels different when you are waking it. All guests are provided with safety harness and a helmet. One or several guides are always with the group controlling safety and assisting those need encouragement to complete the course. Usually there are one or two participants in each group that cry "no puedo" or "I can\'t do it", but it is really not that challenging or scary. \nI went there twice with my family, we had good time, you can also combine this trip with a visit to a small town San Jose de Gracia and take a boat tour on the lake.\nI will not go back just for my own entertainment, but I am planning to take my visitors there to enjoy their reaction! Frankly, this is probably the best thing to do in Aguascalientes!

544074349.name: What should have been a nice adventure, turned out to be a disaster!
544074349.author: a TripAdvisor user
544074349.reviewBody:
Don't get me wrong. The views are breathtaking. It is pretty. 
But...
they make you get on those bridges and 2 tirolesas for $350 pesos each person. You have to go with a group and a guide. The bridges are very secure and you are secure too. It feels so safe, you feel you are walking on cement! This place is great if you are not in good condition, as it will require much effort. So if you are looking for adventures, this is not the place for you. 
Unless...
you get in a group with very old people who require more than normal help, and you also land tour guides that have just returned from a trip with 60 people! This happened to me. They should NOT allow tour guides to go to on two tours in a row. They are tired and they do not pay attention. 
Long story short, they had to come rescue us. As I was descending from the tiroleza, the guide thought t he other had me, and I crashed as they did not stop me. I had to attend PT for a month!!!!
I returned to the site after 6 weeks, and this time I saved my money, went hiking and explored the place without having to wait for people or having tour guides that were so exhausted to be able to help.

492329155.name: Not for the faint of heart, amazing hidden gem!
492329155.author: a TripAdvisor user
492329155.reviewBody:
Boca de Tunel is a hidden gem, more exciting than anyone that has visited can explain. Located 45 mins from Aguascalientes, this thrilling experience alone is worth the trip from any place located within driving distance.

Some people may refer to it as “The Zipline (tirolesa)”, but Boca de Tunel is much more than that, in fact, the zipline is not as exciting as some of its thrilling hanging bridges. This experience was created in a canyon located near the town of XYZ. It consists of a series of hanging bridges and two zip lines that allow the visitor to safely walk the entirety of the canyon from the top. Some of these bridges are hanging over more than 100 meters from the bottom of the canyon, they will take your breath away. 

While this is not for everyone given the levels of adrenaline you will experience, the local guides are well trained and equipped to ensure a safe experience. Every time you cross a hanging bridge you do it attaching your harness from a line above your head that will hold you in case you lose control. 

The experience ends at a dam, place in which you will walk down to the water and take a boat that takes you back to the beginning of the canyon. 

They offer two routes, if you have the time take the long one, it will be worth it. Whoever conceived this experience deserves to be recognized and this should become a staple of Aguascalientes.

667028357.name: Amazing place to sit and chill
667028357.author: a TripAdvisor user
667028357.reviewBody:
From Plaza Patria walk past the Basilica and along Mocteyuma, then Venustiano Carranza and then keep going straight - Is about a 10 minute walk from the Plaza...
Well worth it for some wonderful shade and cool atmosphere.
The Gardens are very well kept and there is plenty of seating on the shade too!
There a water feature in the center, and a bandstand too. When I was there there were a few vendors walking thru with ice cream and cold drinks too!
Some street sellers selling artifacts bracelets etc.
And a musician playing his guitar...
Lovely ambiance and great place to sit with a book for a couple of hours to avoid the midday sun!
Highly recommend :-)

517212644.name: Beautifully maintained park
517212644.author: a TripAdvisor user
517212644.reviewBody:
Jardin de San Marcos is a beautiful, peaceful place.  It is a good place for a stroll or to sit and watch the world go by.  In the center of the park there is a beautiful gazebo that children love.

The park has various walking paths that are lined with park benches.  Grab yourself a place in the shade and watch the families and lovers stroll.

The plantings are very nice, although as a gardener I noticed that there isn't a huge variety of plants.  Having said that, everything is green, trimmed nicely, and well cared for.

The street that leads to the park from the Plaze de la Patria is one of the city's few touristy streets.  There are nice cafes and clothing stores along the way.  If you walk directly through the park, there is another cathedral on the other side.  If you walk to the left of the cathedral, beware.  You will be entering the "hawker" restaurant area with hawkers out front of the restaurants trying to pull you in to their restaurant.  That's always so annoying.

Many people are having ice cream in the park.  Vendors on both ends of the park or across the street from the park sell ice cream. There are also vendors selling small plastic toys for children and sweet goodies.

300590339.name: Nice park near El Centro
300590339.author: a TripAdvisor user
300590339.reviewBody: I liked this park (and the Plaza de Las Centurias, farther from central A.C.).  Like many city parks in many capital cities throughout Mexico, this is a small, lush, peaceful retreat with singing birds, a beautiful gazebo, clean walkways and benches, lined with trash receptacles (use them!), and a few bronze sculptures (very much like Plaza del Carmen in San Luis Potos\u00ed). Food vendors, restaurants, the Templo de San Marcos, and the bullfighting ring can all be found nearby.  Good for daytime relaxing or an evening stroll. \nEnjoy Aguascalientes!

address.streetAddress: Barrio de San Marcos

297717777.name: A Highlight to any trip!
297717777.author: a TripAdvisor user
297717777.reviewBody: These delightful gardens are still a delightful add on to your trip! Be sure to visit at night, so that you can wander through with the young lovers, the joyful families and the pensive writers. There are plenty of vendors with fresh fruit waters and fruits as well as corn and candies and other treats that are sure to make your walk in the garden absolutely memorable. Listen the musicians play and grab a bench to people watch. This is the best place to unwind from the day.

address.streetAddress: Barrio de San Marcos

297535992.name: Classic park in the middle of the city. Worth a visit!
297535992.author: a TripAdvisor user
297535992.reviewBody:
There are not that many parks in Mexico´s main cities, so this is like an Oasis. Enclosed by sculpted columns, it´s packed with benches and bronze sculptures and filled with lush trees that take you away from the usual city rush. 

The San Marcos Church (another city landmark) is just a few metres walk, and there are usually some street stalls with local candy and bites, as well as handicrafts and toys. 

There are also some bars and restaurants nearby well suited for tourists and locals alike.

address.streetAddress: Barrio de San Marcos

Also, across, the street is a cute little place to buy ice cream and fresh fruit cups.  My daughter recommends the jicama with chili.

517591291.author: a TripAdvisor user
517591291.reviewBody: Beautiful temple built around 1773.  Inside you can find the venerated Cristo negro - or black Christ. The legend is that a resident was cutting an oak tree (encino) and found Jesus in the tree.

itemReviewed.name: Templo del Cristo Negro del Encino

address.streetAddress: Barrio del Encino

653287846.name: Great to go chill and watch the World go by... Or a 106 year ceremony!
653287846.author: a TripAdvisor user
653287846.reviewBody:
Walking around downtown and going for breakfast we saw this ceremony taking place in Plaza Patria... So took and seat and watched.
Celebrating 106 years since a battle..
Full army presence and 4 hummers, 3 open top infantry carriers... About 50 soldiers too. Great ceremony topped off by raising the flag...
So when finished all the dignitaries came down from the stage to mingle and chat with the public. nice!
So off for breakfast and came back 90 minutes later - All army had gone and the square is back to normal...
Go look at the Aguascalientes sign, take a photo too!
I sat in the square and read my book for an hour... Watching the World go by - Food sellers in one corner  - so buy a snack...
OXXO in each corner so buy a drink too!
Opposite side there is a covered seating by some water to grab some shade..
So go sit chill, eat drink and watch the World pass you by.... You deserve it :-)

298506808.author: a TripAdvisor user

252833233.name: The site, the guide
252833233.author: a TripAdvisor user
252833233.reviewBody:
We had gone to see the "Broken Christ". Our guide decided that I was sufficiently curious about Mexico that I should see the murals of the Palacio de Gobernio. This palace was built in the 1700

First, It has to be said that those murals were executed by Guillermo Cuellar Arellano, a star pupil of Diego Rivera, the painter who  did the murals of the Palacio Nacional of Mexico D.F.

Those murals are really magnificent and tell the history of Mexico as it applies to Aguascalientes.

I was lucky enough to have Christian as a guide who not only knows the stories but loves to tell them. A visit with him is really worth it. You can get him to teach you about Aguascalientes thru Meshico tour operator.

address.streetAddress: Plaza de la Patria s/n Centro de Aguascalientes

236975831.name: Murals
236975831.author: a TripAdvisor user
236975831.reviewBody: It almost seems to required that important governmental buildings be decorated with spectacular murals, and this one was no exception. (Copying Mexico City maybe?) I found Aguascalientes to be a bit drab; these murals were not!

123090085.author: a TripAdvisor user
123090085.reviewBody: Remarkable building with imposing murals.   Its notable the central imperial staircase, the 101 arches in carved pink stone, and its red volcanic stone in its walls that armoniously survive from centuries ago.

121267342.name: the murals,the day we appreciate them they will charge us to  see it.
121267342.author: a TripAdvisor user
121267342.reviewBody: The murals are a visual book that illustrate you four hundred years of the state history, I feel attracted because my name is related to the builder and original owner, I don\'t know if he was my relative,his name is Juan Rincon de Vivar,so when I get in the palace I do get shaked, my family has been in the state for almost four centuries and every time I\'am in the building I feel scared because looks too solemn to be still standing,beutifull,nice clean an imponent place to be,I highly recommend a visit to it,.thanks,Max Vivar.11-30-2011

address.streetAddress: Plaza de la Patria s/n Centro de Aguascalientes

641656482.name: An excellent museum
641656482.author: a TripAdvisor user
641656482.reviewBody: This place shows the relevant story of Jos\u00e9 Guadalupe Posada. It contains incredible pieces of printing of this personality of the Mexican history.

611617918.name: It is a very interesting Museum with a lot of interaction. We traveled with our 6 year old girl who was very impressed.
611617918.author: a TripAdvisor user
611617918.reviewBody: is a place not to miss, full of nice art and history. There\u00b4s even space to interact with artists and you could learn doing cards with your kids. Absolutely loved it. My six year old had a lot of fun made cards and learned Posadas technique. The staff is very nice also.

598867654.name: Big collection
598867654.author: a TripAdvisor user
598867654.reviewBody: Is a small but with a big collection of plaques designed by Guadalupe Posadas. Every work tell you a story of Mexico, it is a lovely experience. At the end children can use the technique to make they own prints

563617465.name: A good place for Mexican history
563617465.author: a TripAdvisor user
563617465.reviewBody: I\u2019m glad I found out about this guy because he is such an important figure in Mexican history, born in Aguascalientes! A vert talented print maker and a keen eye for satire. A must-do if you\u2019re traveling to the city.

541007253.name: So much fun!
541007253.author: a TripAdvisor user
541007253.reviewBody: Posada was a very interesting character and this museum really allows you to know him and his work with great displays and very good explanations. It was so much fun to go through those old pages full of sensationalist news with the amazing political cartoons of Posada and the awesome writing of the journalists that worked with him. Totally worth a visit!

503667021.name: Small, but relevant museum
503667021.author: a TripAdvisor user
503667021.reviewBody: Jos\u00e9 Guadalupe Posada is one of the most famous and beloved mexican artist. He was a master of engraving. Although he was not an intelectual figure, his importance in popular culture is undeniable. He was the author of Catrina, the female skeleton that symbolize death and one of mexican most treasured icons. He was born in Aguascalientes, where is sited this museum.

475834805.name: Amazing!
475834805.author: a TripAdvisor user
475834805.reviewBody: I didn\'t know anything about Posada, and I learned about the existance of this museum when I arrived in Aguascalientes. I really enjoyed my visit and learned so much about him and the birth of the "Catrina": I would have stayed the whole day in  the museum just to read all the newspapers, because it would have been worth it! I stayed for over an hour in the end and I am very glad to have been here! \n\nI am not sure if you would be able to enjoy the museum if you don\'t understand Spanish, but if you do I definitely recommend it! I would also recommend a visit to the gift shop: the lady is really friendly and helpful, and the souvenirs are very cheap!

470383576.name: If you are in Aguascalientes do not miss this museum
470383576.author: a TripAdvisor user
470383576.reviewBody: It is difficult that one does not recognize Jose Guadalupe Posada\'s prints where skeletons dance lively and skulls are all over. Besides these more popular prints, Posada created hundreds of images for local newspapers with strong political content, narrating the daily life and problems of Mexicans in the late XIX  beginning of XX Centuries. The museum is on a beautiful historical house. The collection is stunning.while it is well curated and well displayed. Do not miss it!

468155129.name: The Fascinating Posada Museum in Aguascalientes
468155129.author: a TripAdvisor user
468155129.reviewBody:
La Catrina, the grinning skeleton with the elegant, floppy chapeau, is, without a doubt, the most famous creation of Mexican cartoonist, illustrator, artist and satirist, José Guadalupe Posada (1852-1913) whose work was so prolific that even today no one knows exactly how many obras he produced. But if you’d like an overview of his work—and at the same time an insight into life in Mexico during the tumultuous days of the Revolution—the place you have to visit is the Posada Museum in Aguascalientes.

Posada, who was born in the city of Aguascalientes, first did his engravings on wood and in 1895 introduced the technique of etching on blocks of zinc. Mostly he did cartoons which were accompanied by verses or popular news items. The papers he worked for were penny publications, the precursors of today’s supermarket tabloids, and he illustrated countless tales of murder and mayhem as well as graphic reports of catastrophes and dire predictions of cataclysms.

Posada’s first well-known representation of people portrayed as skeletons was his etching of a bony Don Quixote, published in 1905. From then on the calavera became his trademark. Calavera literally means “skull” but in most cases his calveras were complete skeletons. In 1912, near the end of his career, Posada drew his most famous calavera, La Catrina. Guides at the Posada Museum take pains to point out that, originally, Catrina was in no way related to the Day of the Dead, nor a mystical symbol of the inevitability of Death, so predominant in pre-Hispanic Mexico.

In reality, Posada’s Catrina poked fun at Mexico City’s high society during the Porfiriato, when French fashions were all the rage. Even the servants and garbanceras—ladies selling chick peas in the street—wanted to look catrín (fancy) and, one way or another would borrow something French-looking to wear in public, whitening their dark skin with powder, in imitation of Porfirio Díaz himself, who went to lengths to hide his mestizo origins.

During all of his life, Posada worked for someone else, illustrating verses or stories written by other people. “Posada does not want to reform or change society: he wants to depict it,” said Octavio Paz. Nevertheless, he did such a good job at it, that Diego Rivera included José Guadalupe Posada among the 150 most emblematic Mexicans in his 1948 mural “Sueño de una tarde dominical en la Alameda,” where we see La Catrina holding hands with Posada and Rivera himself as a young boy.

Sad to say, José Guadalupe Posada died penniless in 1913 and, like Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, was buried in a dirt-cheap grave. Ironically, seven years later the grave was dug up and Posada’s remains were thrown into the cemetery’s “calaveras del montón,” the very “heap of bones” which had appeared so often in his drawings.

Without a doubt, Diego Rivera would have agreed that the Posada Museum—with its collection of 3000 pieces—is well worth a visit. It’s open Tuesday to Sunday, 11 AM to 6 PM. The entrance fee is ten pesos, free on Sunday. TEL (449) 915 4556. You can get there from Guadalajara in about three hours via very good toll roads. See the directions below.

“Death is democratic, because in the end, everybody, whether light-skinned, dark-skinned, rich or poor, ends up as a calavera.”
José Guadalupe Posada

How to get there
Head east out of Guadalajara toward Mexico City. At Zapotlanejo, take toll road 80- northeast past Tepatitlán toward Lagos de Moreno and León. After approximately 150 kilometers, turn left onto toll road 45 which will lead you straight into Aguascalientes. Set your trip odometer at zero as you pass the Siglo XXI ring road. After 3.5 kilometers watch for Profra. Vicenta Trujillo Street and turn right.  After 230 meters, Turn right again onto Dr Jesús Díaz de León. You’ll find the museum 100 meters farther on, on your right, at the north end of beautiful Jardín del Encino. The address is Calle Vicente Trujillo 222 (GPS coordinates: 21° 52.507 N, 102° 17.566 W).

426481202.name: well organised
426481202.author: a TripAdvisor user
426481202.reviewBody: This museum is designed in an interesting manner where you wander through the gallery.\nUnfortunately there was no English in the descriptions but art does not need language.\nI would think that it would be worth making a small handout in English to introduce this artist.

351416929.name: Very Interesting
351416929.author: a TripAdvisor user
351416929.reviewBody: Posada is famous for creating the original Contrina design in the 1910\'s.  The museum is full of Posada\'s work from newspaper articles, children\'s books and his relationship with many notable persons of the day.  Interesting.

350409778.name: Extraordinarily well-done!
350409778.author: a TripAdvisor user
350409778.reviewBody: We actually planned this trip to Aguascalientes just because of this museum, and it does not disappoint.  There is no info in English, but I took pictures of all of the wonderful signage and I\'ll work on eventually sorting that out ;)  Seeing all of the zinc plates and wooden blocks was wonderful, as well as seeing the truth breadth of his work.  It\'s small but a true gem, especially for 10 pesos (and free on Wednesdays).

306488885.name: Dishonest ticket agent
306488885.author: a TripAdvisor user
306488885.reviewBody: My family and I visited Museo Posada Sunday afternoon 8/30/15. The ticket prices were $10 pesos per person. I placed a $200 pesos bill on the counter top to pay for 4 tickets. The ticket agent, a middle age man, maybe 5\' 7\'\' with little hair and olive colored skin placed the $200 pesos bill behind the counter top still in sight. I turned to my family to ask for a smaller bill so the agent would not have to give back so much change. We made he transaction with a smaller bill. The ticket agent then replaced my original $200 peso bill with a $100 and played dumb when I indicated this was not correct. At that point I knew I had been cheated $100 pesos. I indicated my displeasure but didn\'t want to make a big fuss in a foreign country where I did not speak the language. So watch your pesos here better than I did. This experience diminished our enjoyment of Museo Posada.

297717989.name: Great Remodel
297717989.author: a TripAdvisor user
297717989.reviewBody: Can\'t beat this location, so much to take in and see! Enjoy all the offerings this museum has to offer, but skip their caf\u00e9 and enjoy the atmosphere of Caf\u00e9 Con Sentido, just on the other side of the garden!

240983415.name: Not just Catrinas!
240983415.author: a TripAdvisor user
240983415.reviewBody: Here you learn what Jose Guadalupe Posada did during his time life.  There are lots of engravings, newspaper articles,  and prints where you can actually see how he evolved.  It is interesting to read about  what was going on in Mexico during that time and the way people perceived natural phenomenon such as earthquakes, as God punishment or the end of the world approaching. You learn that the name Catrina was given by Diego Rivera and not Posada

235249320.name: For artists, a fab museum
235249320.author: a TripAdvisor user
235249320.reviewBody: Great layout and explanations in, largely, Spanish. Podosa was a gifted artist, illustrator, of newspapers and books at the end of the 19th and beginning of 20th century. To see the blocks he made from lead or zinc to create political, topical, mythical and religious illustration - often side beside the published work - was really interesting to an artist. You have to have an interest in art techniques or the struggle for Mexican independence otherwise you\'ll probably be bored and end up sitting in the pretty square outside... Which is also more than worthwhile for a glimpse of neighbourhood life!

206540881.name: Not for passing fans of his work.
206540881.author: a TripAdvisor user
206540881.reviewBody: My opinion is that one needs a grasp of Spanish, and Mexican history to get much from this museum. Much of the artwork is all rather tame compared to the works he is widely known for. He did have a style of work, but that is not enough to keep you interested for long. Not a great deal at all is given over to WHO he was. The satire involved with his work may be lost on some, as it was with us. Of course his work is relevant. I do not mean to discount this museum. I only hope to get this review across to someone who may not know much about him or his work. In my opinion this is for serious enthusiasts of his.

183590519.name: Basic but very interesting
183590519.author: a TripAdvisor user
183590519.reviewBody: Warning: to enjoy this museum you have to understand who Posada was. If you do, you will really enjoy seeing his work and learning about the times he lived in and the role he assumed in reporting on them. It\'s a very basic museum but at only 10 pesos admission, it is well worth a visit.

175460080.name: Must see for designers and journalists
175460080.author: a TripAdvisor user
175460080.reviewBody: In it, we learn the Posada\'s work goes far beyond Catrina, and had a very interesting political presence through newspapers and child books.

162743621.name: Interesting, but weeeeird weird tour guide
162743621.author: a TripAdvisor user
162743621.reviewBody: Went to this museum last year.  There are a lot of interesting historical facts to be learned, but the guided tour was painfully dull and the tour guide tended to go off on random tangents.  At one point she actually swore during the tour, which took me aback - not something you want to bring your (Spanish speaking) children to, haha.

154727599.name: a place you must visit
154727599.author: a TripAdvisor user
154727599.reviewBody: museum for people like at and historicalsocial behaivor, very interesting place dedicated to an extrardinary artist talented in what he was gifted, very well kept and very well displayed you can spend 30 minutes or two days but you will enjoy the expirience

114886891.name: Amazing place for dia de Los muertos fans
114886891.author: a TripAdvisor user
114886891.reviewBody: This place was one of the most interesting museums Ive ever been in, and trust me there have been a lot! In case you don\'t know Posado was responsible for many of the images we see associated with Dia de Los Muertos as well as many other images. \nVery informative, great gift shop and super cheap entry. The biggest drawback was that everything was in Spanish only and my Spanish isn\'t very good.\nIt is small and makes a great day if you take a cab to the nearby Museo Muerte.

11931100.name: A Wonderful Museum!
11931100.author: a TripAdvisor user
11931100.reviewBody: The Museo Posada was a pleasant surprise in Aguascalientes.  Posada was a originator of the "Catrina" image that is so prevelant in Mexico.  In fact, a young Diego Rivera spent time observing Posada at work in Mexico City and was a large influence in Mr. Rivera\'s life.  \n\nThe museum itself, while small, was very well laid out.  It included a wide assortment of his prints along side the actual plates that correspond to each print.  The museum faced a lively plaza that makes for enjoyable people watching.  The only problem with the museum is that there is no information available in English.  However, this is not much of a problem because the prints speak for themselves.

621549106.name: More of the same
621549106.author: a TripAdvisor user
621549106.reviewBody: Noisy, not varied and long lines for a cup of coffee or ice cream. Not worth it. I think there are better things to do here

612981332.author: a TripAdvisor user
612981332.reviewBody: Excelente museo con unas instalaciones de primera. Fuimos a ver la exposici\u00f3n \u201cClaroscuro\u201dde Javier Mar\u00edn y fue una experiencia grandiosa. La mejor atenci\u00f3n de las personas del museo, muchas gracias nos hicieron sentir como en casa. Vale la pena visitar. 100% recomendable.
